comments:
Feb. 14th 8:00am build
observed with linux-gtk and linux-motif, probably happens elsewhere as well

- start eclipse at the command line
- in the workspace selection dialog press Cancel, which exits
- start eclipse at the command line again
- this time it fails quite quickly, with the following log written to the configuration directory:

As a follow-up, I've found that if I do select a workspace instead of cancelling that eclipse still fails to start up.  So this may be linux-specific, since the corresponding win32 build did start for me.
Maybe timing related?  Can you clear your configuration directory (exept the config.ini) and try again?

These problems happen consistently for me with both gtk and motif.  My exact steps:

- download eclipse
- cd to its directory, tar zxvf it
- cd eclipse
- ln -s /opt/jre .
- ./eclipse &
- <cancel the workspace selection dialog>
- ./eclipse &
- <fails>
sorry, my jre wasn't valid, closing report
Just curious, is that a commonly used VM available to the public.  If so it would be useful to know that eclipse does not support it.

It was a 1.4.1 vm, which I've been using for quite a while (in fact it seemed to work fine for eclipse up to the last milestone).  I see that the minimum required is 1.4.2 though, so it's not the fault of the vm.  The IBM 1.4.1 vm on aix failed in an identical manner.

At least now if anyone logs a report with a trace similar to the one above then you can take a good guess at what their problem is.
I suddenly started getting similar exceptions on WinXP using 1.4.1 as well.

I can reproduce on 1.4.1 VMs.  This is a really strange one.  The 1.4.1 VMs do not seem to always use the correct classloader when attempting to load classes when refection is used.  For some reason the org.eclipse.equinox.regitry bundle's classloader is be used in the reflection calls to load the org.eclipse.core.runtime.Plugin class.  This should never happen.  The 1.4.1 VM seems to be confused.

Maybe that is a reason we don't support that version of the VM?  I think this has popped up recently with the runtime split which causes more classloaders to be used and hence the confusion in the 1.4.1 VM.
*** Bug 152879 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 150672 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
